title: Ares
introduction: Ares is the Greek god of war, bloodshed, and violence, embodying the brutal and chaotic nature of battle. Unlike Athena, who represents strategic warfare, Ares is associated with the raw, aggressive, and destructive aspects of conflict. He was often viewed with ambivalence by the Greeks, who respected his power but also saw him as reckless and unpredictable. Despite his fearsome nature, Ares played a significant role in mythology, particularly in stories involving battles, rivalries, and his passionate love affairs. His worship was more prominent in regions such as Thrace, where he was considered a powerful and revered deity.
mythicHistory:
Ares was the son of Zeus and Hera, but unlike many Olympian gods, he was not widely admired. Zeus himself often expressed disdain for Ares, criticizing his impulsive and bloodthirsty tendencies. In battle, Ares was not always victorious; he was wounded in the Trojan War by the mortal hero Diomedes with Athenaâ€™s help, demonstrating that brute force alone was not enough to guarantee success in war. Despite his strength, Ares frequently found himself outmatched by other gods.

One of Ares' most famous myths involves his love affair with Aphrodite, the goddess of love and beauty, despite her being married to Hephaestus. Their secret relationship was exposed when Hephaestus trapped them in a golden net and humiliated them before the other gods. This myth highlights Ares' passionate and reckless nature, as well as his tendency to act on impulse without considering the consequences. His affair with Aphrodite resulted in several children, including Eros (Cupid), the god of love, and Harmonia, the goddess of harmony, ironically balancing his chaotic nature.

Ares also played a role in myths involving his mortal children and followers. He was the father of the Amazon queen Penthesilea, who fought and died in the Trojan War. He also had a son, Cycnus, who attempted to build a temple out of human skulls before being slain by Heracles. Despite his flaws, Ares was still honored in certain aspects of Greek society, particularly among warriors who sought his favor in battle, even though he was often depicted as a god of strife rather than victory.
